notes: Fou a spring just above the discharge center/structure. Small flow a possibly connect to the stream we prevously sampled. Comes from a hole a there are other holes arou where it looks like flow used to emerge from as well. Lots of thorny shrubs. Lots of down trees. Right alongside the Coe River
Hiked in on Eliot Glacier Trail rather than taking Cooper Spur. Dropped down into Eliot Catchment. This is the first stream sample from the farthest point down catchment.

Stream emerging from center of hummocky terrain that I believe is the terminus of the debris part of Eliot. Extremely steep walls surrouing "subglacial" flow. There is a small snowpack with algae on it right above the emergence. For safety purposes, we sampled the subglacial flow slightly downstream. Lots of long stringy brown/green algae in the stream.
Spring looked the same as last year.
Tried to fi GPS coordinates, no luck. Decided to sample in the stream instead because we couldn't fi the source. Flow is high a water is clear. Lots of thick vegetation.
This stream is much more murkey/darker brown in color. Subglacial melt. Ice actively melting into stream.

On left side of catchment there was an exposure of ice melting into a pool a forming a stream. It was dirty a the ice looked cracked. It looked like it was ice stuck into the side of the moraine a melting out. Active ice a rock falling into pool. Very saturated sediment arou the pool.

Collected 1L a 250mL. Was told about this spring from multiple NPS people. They drink straight from it a it runs year rou. It has been piped for easy access. We sampled from the source at the rock face.

notes: Emergence higher here than last year. This year there is a pool where there is a headcut/bowl shape. Water is upwelling from the rocks filling the base of this bowl. Pool drains out over some rocks/logs. It looks like it did flow at least another 6" higher out of the pool a few weeks ago, based on old moss/algae that was matted down in the flowing direction.

notes: Everything looks the same at this spring with the exception of less vegetation. It looks like this spring is accessed by hikers, etc. The flowers a vegetation look stepped on. Emergence was the same, perhaps slightly less flow.

When we visited Eliot moraine seeps we saw a snowpack that I believe contained snow algae. We hiked up today to get samples of it. It's completely separate from other snowpack. It's tucked away into a valley a is slowly infiltrating as it's melting. Maybe this signature will come up in Eliot Moraine Seep spring that we sampled.

Collected another sample farther down stream in mcdonald creek in throught that contributions from other upstream tribs from glaciers would give a different signature/mixing profile. Collected isotopes, gen chem, h3, cl36, a strontium.

notes: At the source we sampled from it is untreated. Afterwards it is treated with chlorine. Flow is immense. There is a large stream composed of the water that they down take for drinking water a that is still significant.
Appeared the same last year.
unit_notes: thickness ranges from 530 to 790 m

notes: No YSI. Solid snow. Collected both surface (algae) snow a below. Looked like snowpack from the previous year.
Dirty glacial ice on the left side. Caelum was suspeed by rope to collect this sample.
There was exposed ice at the previous stream site. We are sampling here because this is a much cleaner sample of ice. There was a distinct debris layer on top of the glacier.

Hiked in from Cloud Cap Campgrou. Trail was washed out. Took moraine trail in. The moraine was very recently scoured from the recent snow. The moaine was missing Jeff a my trail. We tried to collect glacier ice from where I get snow algae normally but there was so much snow pack. We looked into a crevasse that went down ~4ft a it was all snow. The whole glacier is covered in snow but there are many crevasses present. We could hear a channel of water uer the snow pack. It's loud. The waterfall was gone too. Bees, flies, hummingbirds, skiers present.

Eliot glacier. Spring originated from beneath a rock. No sign of spring above, but there was a spring to the immediate left of this spring. I assume they share the same internal source. There was another spring that was mapped a it was a bit farther to the left of these two a it's source looked like a seep which was covered with moss. I was not sure how to sample it, so I sampled the one lower on the mountain.
Sampled headwaters of the main tilly jane stream. It is very close to Eliot Spring. The channel is lined by moss in the riperian zone a there are small pine trees in the emergence.
Zach did 10mg of salt for the meter in the 500 mL bottle.
Subglacial stream on Eliot glacier. Brown colored water from clay like sediment on glacier upstream

Hiked up Cooper Spur trail to get some fresh snow.

The source of this is unkown. Sampling chlorine 36, tritium, strontium, gen chem anyway. Look up the source on imagery. It has a very general SPC a temp, so it's hard to tell anything from this location without being able to see the emergence. The water is flowing from a series of very high a steep cliffs. Vegetation is thick here too. Purple a yellow flowers a those strong tree bush things.

Collected 1 bag, 2 feet in depth of snowpack. Overall there was much less snowpack this year than last. Many more crevasses as well. Rock felt more loose than before too.
Same GPS location as snow-1
Collected CFC slightly south along seepage face bc we needed a gradient. Collected 1L, 250mL, bio, a isotope at the same emergence as last year.

Gave 4 250mL bottles to some ice climbers at Cloud Cap Campgrou. They returned 2 bottles with a few mL's of glacial ice a 1 bottle with a few mL of snow.

I saw large seeps on google earth in a moraine near Eliot Spring. They were persistent from imagery. Upon arrival we noticed that they were seeps on nearly the same elevation on either side of the valley. It look like the valley was eroded out by surface water/rivers a now the seeps are located on either side. We hiked in a it was scary. Very loose rock a unconsolidated. The place we sampled was a seepage face on the left side of the valley looking down elevation from the top of the catchment opening. Flow channelized through the bottom of the valley a joined snow melt from above in a huge stream. There was alot of snow pack uer sediment on the southern slope. We saw a huge boulder crash down that slope. There was a big spring seep on that side too. It looked like it may have been burried glacial ice. That side was too dangerous to access.
No YSI. Solid snow. Collected both surface (algae) snow a below. Looked like snowpack from the previous year.

Hiked in from Cloud Cap Campgrou. Trail was washed out. Took moraine trail in. The moraine was very recently scoured from the recent snow. The moaine was missing Jeff a my trail. We tried to collect glacier ice from where I get snow algae normally but there was so much snow pack. We looked into a crevasse that went down ~4ft a it was all snow. The whole glacier is covered in snow but there are many crevasses present. We could hear a channel of water uer the snow pack. It's loud. The waterfall was gone too. Bees, flies, hummingbirds, skiers present.
Used ice axe to break off ~1.5 ft of ice exposed at a subglacial flow. Waited until ice melted in baggies, then transported it to bottles.

Collected 2 1L, a 250mL, a a bio sample. It used to be piped into sherwood campgrou, but the EPA shut down all water sources in the campgrous. This one they just cut the pipe a it's freely flowing to the grou out of the pipe. There were some small seeps of water above the pipe, but it seemed like the majority of water was being funnled through the pipe. It was situated in a rocky drainage.
Farther down the catchment we got some meltwater. We think this would be good for strontium because we can compare it to the other springs here
This looks like it may have been glacial ice, a it began melting. So, this may be an integration of both snow a ice.

Fou it exactly where the USGS point was. Lots of flow. Looks like it's coming from a contact. Flow comes out of a plane of rock along side the road. Lots of moss a shrubs along the seepage face. Also rock is present here too. Stream forms alongside the road but majority flows uer the road. Zach did discharge on the stream on the other side of the road. There are also rasperries, red berries, white daisies, 2 kis of purple flowers, yellow flowers, a ferns present.
Also collected 1L, 2 250mL samples

At the location where the White River Glacier Runoff meets the bridge on 35. Thougth is that if we can't sample the glacial melt, this is the closest we can do. There has been a lot of precip over the past week so this drainage is likely draining a large portion of runoff from rain/snow at the time of sampling.

notes: Hiked up from Meadows Ski Area. Several streams drain into the meadow's catchment. Followed one up a to the left. Spring is emerging from base of rock. The flow is strong. Seems to be flowing uer soil/root coverage. Caelum sawa a rodent from a nearby hole. Caddisfly was also spotted.

notes: Lots of flow coming directly from fountain. It is piped through. Fills up a pool. Note on tree saying "water not treated". People came a drank from it anyway. Lots of moss growing. Filtered from the "source". It looks like the emergence used to be to the right, but then after the spring box was built the flow preferentially went there. That is where the rocks were taken from, the paleoemergence.

notes: Zach did 10mg of salt for the meter in the 500 mL bottle. Hike in on Newton Trail, then take Timberline Trail. The hill we sample on is a pyroclastic flow. There are numerous holes, almost karst-like on the slope. There is thick vegetation a lots of down pine trees. The spring we sampled from is a hole, but there are two additional exits south, slightly left of the spring. There are yellow flowers a white, lots of green leafy plants too. Zach took discharge downslope where a bunch of these karst like springs all combine a form a stream.

Tried to fi Palmer Spring (USGS point), no luck. On the hike in along the trail I crossed a few streams a marked them in case we needed to follow them up to the source. When we tried to fi Palmer Spring, we decided to walk towards "spring run" in the GPS. We eed up at a flat spot in a meadow a fou a large seepage face. There was channelized flowing water too. We sampled from a flowing pool of wter. There was moss a we were in a soily zone. Purple flowers a lots of flies. Probably channelized together channelized quickly from these seeps. We forgot to record ysi readings at the site, so we just recorded it at the stream on the trail because that was the same water.
Went to Buzzard Fountain. Fou spring box with frog in it. Followed up the mountain to the source. Similar emergence to Camp Wiy or Tilly Jane. Small caddisfly was present. Collected 1L, 2 250mL. UF.

First warm spring. Entered Still Creek Campgrou. Drove down along campgrou road until a picnic area was seen. This is Barlow Road/Trail. Take the trail a go to the old swimming pool fouation. Hang a left a you'll fi a stream. This is MS-7 on the Wollenberg 1979 paper.
Hiked upstream. Eventually came to the main emergence. Large (4') diameter pool from uer a rock. Thorny plants are nearby a along stream. I think this is MS-9 on Wollenberg's paper.

YSI from where the first seepy spring emerges. There are small holes a mosses all arou this emergence. There is snowpack slightly uphill. Possible straight snowpack melt seeping through the tallus that's all over here. The pH meter is acting up. Threre seems to be a contact here. The area is covered w float from a red/maroon ripple marked claystone. There are additional seeps/springs down below. Unsure if they are separate emergences or have a stronger grouwater component?

notes: Sampled from highest seep. Unsure is this is acceptable for CFCs. Paul held the tubing down with his ha a we gravity pumped it. Lots of other emergences arou here too, but this was the highest with a clear emergence. Collected bio, isotopes, CFC, 1L, 250mL.
Spring looked the same as last year. Collected CFC, bio, 1L, a 250mL. Need to pipette isotope in lab.
Also collected DNA, isotope, 1L, 250mL. Saw caddisfly.
Used a ~4ft long stick to plumb emergence for CFCs. Lots of caddisfly shells. Collected 1L, 250mL, bio, isotope.
Refilled 1L a 250mL with this unfiltered water bc this was a new sample site a we didn't have extra bottles or a clean DNA kit. Isotopes collected in Falcon Tube. We collected for CFCs here.

On the eastern side is where we samples. I also collected some squishy orange/brown algal mat that was to the left of the emergence, about 2" to the left.

This is the same sample as the "screen springs" from the Wollenberg paper. There is a screen in the stream just downsteam from the emergence. There is a bunch of what looks like calcite precipitating onto the rocks in all of these warm springs. The rocks have calcite ~4" above the current stream height. I think this iicates a change in water level depeing on the time of year. Red bricks were also in the stream channel.

Spring location given by fire chief. On google maps as Rubideau Spring. Big cement structure like Mt. hood crystal spring surrouing the spring. It may be treated? Pipe like flow discharging water into fast flowing channel. Piped flow lovings remaier of water to location down in elevation.

notes: Lisa from NPS wildlife gave us these coordins. Go to Packer's Roost Trailhead a walk about a half mile to a foot bridge. Then follow up to an emergence. High flow. Emergence from uer a rock. There is a big bowl shape here where it looks like it's emerged in the past. Rocks are wet back there a still moss covered a algae/slimy to the west there is a small bowl. it looks like it's a topo high. It's cooler a darker with thicker vegetation here. No flowers, just green plants/shrubs/ferns. Stonefly spotted. Numerous emergences in area mostly emerging from sick soil zone.

notes: Crack in wall where it emerges is karst in nature. Looks like it began as a fracture a over time caused a cavity out of the limstone. Algal mat at emergence a patches of mosses all over the wall. Flow is pretty high. Emergence is about 10 ft up on wall. Filter is very clean. Able to gravity pump. Really no sediment here. Bunch of flowers on drainage along side of the road but no flowers by emergence.

Collected 1 250mL, 1L, CFCs, bio, isotope. Spring emerges from bedding plane at high rate of discharge. CFCs were collected from within upwelling crack. These CFCs were broken in transit to the lab, so I flew back out a recollected the samples on 8/15/18 at 10:04am. The new YSI measurements are the following: 0.4, 591.6, 78.1, 11.29, 15.1, 8.0, 9.75, 7.68, 174.4. I collected A, B, C, D, E CFC bottles this time a shipped A-C to the lab.

notes: Overall, very heavily crevassed glacier. Both lateral a longitudinal crevasses, thick snowpack too. We crossed a small snow bridge to get to the glacier ice. To get to this side of the cirque, we had to cross a glacial stream. We got heavy rain last night. The lake ahead of the ice is huge. There are a few icebergs near the north e of the lake. 2 main waterfalls drain salamaer glacier. Only birds, a few grassy/mossy protected spots, a a few small flies were seen. Saw a baby black bear on the hike in too.

notes: This spring complex feeds into still creek. We sampled from main largest source. Lots of yellow flowers. On a rather steep hill. Water is clean a cold a pouring out. Very easily accessible from the car. Lots of mosquitoes.

This is the source of water for Gov't Camp. There are a few spring emergences in one region (fenced). Greg Wanner showed us this one. There seems to be maybe a contact here causing these springs to pop out. The flow is a lot. There are also pipes bringing this additional flow from the other spring emergences within this zone into one area where there is a spring box that runs to the pipes for gov't camp. Trees, bushes, thorny plants, salmon berries, huckelberries.

Overall, very heavily crevassed glacier. Both lateral a longitudinal crevasses, thick snowpack too. We crossed a small snow bridge to get to the glacier ice. To get to this side of the cirque, we had to cross a glacial stream. We got heavy rain last night. The lake ahead of the ice is huge. There are a few icebergs near the north e of the lake. 2 main waterfalls drain salamaer glacier. Only birds, a few grassy/mossy protected spots, a a few small flies were seen. Saw a baby black bear on the hike in too.
unit_notes: thickness ranges from 750 m in most of park to a maximum of about 1,030 m in southwestern part; generally subdivisible into three parts at most exposures in park

notes: At the base of chief mountain on hidden lake trail there is a small po. It's recharged by a seepage face. Bright green moss where seepage is occuring. Stone fly larvae (I think) on rock where seepage is happening. Above us, clinging onto the base of cheif mtn is snowpack. I think this is the same contact as what we sampled last. We also collected snowpack at the last stop. There is a larger moraine at the base of cheif mtn. Flow from this seep is running a channelizes a then flows into a large seepy pool.
unit_notes: at type section at Snowslip Mountain in southern part of park, the Snowslip is informally subdivided into six members designated 1 through 6 in ascending order; members are not mapped separately but can be recognized in exposures throughout park

notes: Hiked up Lunch Creek over the ridge a then located the spring down in the drainage. Checked out Piegan glacier but it was too steep to access. Went down into the drainage a the whole area is ki of hummocky a lumpy a there's a bunch of moss. There was a clean emergence through. This side of the mtn (NE of piegan glacier) is more eroded into tallus slope. There are some units of bedrock poking through through. There are a few patches of snow still up on the tallus. Grass a small flowers. pika a flies a grasshoppers.
unit_notes: thickness ranges from 750 m in most of park to a maximum of about 1,030 m in southwestern part; generally subdivisible into three parts at most exposures in park

notes: This is where we sampled. Emergence seems to be from a grey colored siltstone, not out of the maroon layer. Flow is fast. I think still snowmelt driven. Noah sampled lower downstream a it had the same YSI readings as Reynolds 1. Emergence from rock not moss.
unit_notes: at type section at Snowslip Mountain in southern part of park, the Snowslip is informally subdivided into six members designated 1 through 6 in ascending order; members are not mapped separately but can be recognized in exposures throughout park

notes: Side of road seeps coming from very chossy rock face, likely blown out by dynomite. Water is not coming from above. Moss growing from seeps, forming small channel alongside the road. The bedding of the outcrop is not parallel to the grou. We sampled from a seep that had the most consistent flow.

Side of road seeps coming from very chossy rock face, likely blown out by dynomite. Water is not coming from above. Moss growing from seeps, forming small channel alongside the road. The bedding of the outcrop is not parallel to the grou. We sampled from a seep that had the most consistent flow.

Tried to fi rocks. No luck. Soil layer too thick here. Spring emerges from uer a tree. Part of a spring complex of west fork salmon creek. Spring shown by greg. Caddisfly fou here. Flow is strong a cold. Vegetation is moss, lots of tree branches down. Infinity pool looking. Filter very clean. Lots of bright green vegetation. Riparian in nature.

Another spring, but closer to lunch creek. Massive emergence. Flowing out from layered stromatelite a limestone/dolostone bedding. Emergence is large enough for me to crawl into. Water is cold a there is vegetation like mosses growing within the karst like emergence/tunnel. Same flowers as last spring. Gnats flying arou. Rare bird that is going extinct was seen. Saw a grou squirrel too. YSI downstream is essentially the same. Fou an ooid rock sample within the karst emergence.
unit_notes: at type section at Snowslip Mountain in southern part of park, the Snowslip is informally subdivided into six members designated 1 through 6 in ascending order; members are not mapped separately but can be recognized in exposures throughout park

notes: Fou a lot of greeen patches down slope from Palmer glacier on sat imagery. Upon investigation they do not have springs here. We sampled one that emerged from below a ridge of a moraine. It emerges from beneath a rock a then goes back uer the rock a emerges a bit downslope. There is a cement pool to catch all of this water. At the weir of this pool. There are strong trees/bushes here at the emergence, while next to the emergence there are no trees or vegetation like this. Just small flowers very close to the grou. There are snow patches arou but this spring is above them. They're in the valley a creating a small creek.

Discharge done 2 m from source where the stream channelized. Hiked to zigzag canyon. Back where it gets tighter the flow channelizes a bit more. There are many seeps in the walls of the canyon. Two larger seeps/spring pop out at higher elevation on the western wall. On the eastern wall there is exposed rock with water flowing from the fractures. There is a spring discharging above this from a good emergence. There are lots of flowers surrouing the emergence too. Small gnats a flies a dragonflies. Below this spring is a conceptual model of small scale scale model of what I think may be happening on a larger scale in some locations.

notes: Tried to fi the source of sa canyon given by Greg, but only fou the main stream of sa canyon. Instead we back tracked a fou a spring emerging in a drainage to the east of that one. Zach did discharge right before the pool. Lots of yellow jackets.

notes: Hiked up lunch creek a then traversed across the topo line. Huge spring coming out of a rock face/cliff. Massive flow. Limestone rock here. Elizabeth Garrits helped us get here. Above tree line. Small brush here a there. Shrubby cinfoil (yellow), aster (purple), fire weed, sulfur buck wheat (yellow)

notes: Collected possible firn (2 bags), snowpack (2 bags) fresh, a glacial ice (3 bags). There is definitely more snowpack present this year than last, but the snowfield we had to cross was not there to get to the crevasses/glacial ice. We were able to hike far out onto the rubble covered ice. We saw the bones from last year too on the rock on top of the glacier.

unit_notes: includes channel and overbank deposits in modern floodplain; in narrow mountain valleys locally includes small areas of colluvium; thickness 1-5 m

notes: This spring is within a small valley on the eastern side of zigzag canyon. At first it appeared that a nearby snowpackk was the driving factor providing flow, but when we went down we saw it is definitely a large spring. It emerges from beneath a tree a a rock with a huge amount of flow. Up valley is dry with no snow pack. The vegetation is sparse here. mall shrubs. No flowers here.

East of old ski lift we fou a small patch of remanant snow. It was heavily melted out.

Hiked up from top of Magnificint Mile Ski Lift. Hike was ~3.3 miles. Took climbers trail up. Got to top near top of upper skilift a fou only snow pack. Rather  thick ~5ft where we took the snow core. Lots of snow algae all over surface. Snow core had at least 3 layers present with ice melt/crystals between. Lots of sweat bees, butterflies, a swallows. We hiked the moraine separating Palmer a White River a the White River glacier appeared to still have a lot of glacial ice present. We couldn't access it though because it was far too deep in the valley. Lots of crevasses a rock fall. There were a lot of skiers a snowboarders here, so the possibility of contamination is high. Collected 3 bags of snow core, 1 bag of upper snow core, 1 bag of lower snow core, 2 bags of surface snow.
Snow sample also collected upslope from spring. Large red streaks present across snow pack.

notes: Went to the GPS coordinates provided by Joe a didn't fi a spring. Instead there were many snowmeltderived pools. We noticed across the way some of those dark seep looking objects on the cliffs, a also fou some accessable ones. They appeared to be markers of both active a inactive seeps. The dark spots/streaks may be relics of areas where water was prevously seeping, a dyed the rock a darker color. The rock itself at first appeared to be cousive to layer a fracture flow, but upon further investigation it seems like only fracture flow is possible. The bedding is very fine, very laminated, layered clay a siltstone. We took a gen chem a rock sample here. Called it sad drip.

Collected overnight from 9/17/19 to 9/18/19. Volume of water collected in each white bin was ~818mL. Collected 3 white bin/pan's worth. Car was running nearby. Might not be great for the samples.
Hid 3 inverted top water bottles. Going back for them on Saturday. Collected 9/21/19 morning. Collector 1: 190mL, Collector 2: 180mL, Collector 3: 194mL
Collected precip while drying off at Timberline Lodge. Poured into 2 250mL bottles. Collected water in 1 white bin/pan.

Hid 2 water bottles with cutoff a inverted tops on the mountain by the Timberline Lodge Lower Parking Lot near Palmer Seep sample. Put them out the morning of 9/18/19. Walked over to see the moraine of White River Glacier. Horrible visibility a very steep moraine. Leaving out collectors to collect until Saturday. Collected 162mL collectively with 2 containers.
